definitions.definition: (of a person or animal) slide unintentionally for a short distance, typically losing one's balance or footing.
(of a thing) accidentally slide or move out of position or from someone's grasp.
examples: the envelope slipped through Luke's fingers
synonyms: slide "the envelope slipped through Luke's fingers"

definitions.definition: fail to grip or make proper contact with a surface.
examples: the front wheels began to slip

definitions.definition: go or move quietly or quickly, without attracting notice.
examples: we slipped out by a back door
synonyms: tiptoe More"we slipped out by a back door"escape
take a powder "they managed to slip away"

definitions.definition: pass or change to a lower, worse, or different condition, typically in a gradual or imperceptible way.
examples: many people feel standards have slipped

definitions.definition: be behaving in a way that is not up to one's usual level of performance.
examples: you're slipping, Joeâ€”you need a vacation

definitions.definition: (of time) elapse.
put (something) in a particular place or position quietly, quickly, or stealthily.
examples: she slipped the map into her pocket
synonyms: stuff "she slipped the map into her pocket"

definitions.definition: put on or take off (a garment) quickly and easily.
examples: put on, pull on, don, dress/clothe oneself in; Morechange into "Sarah slipped into a black skirt"take off, remove, pull off, doff, peel off "she slipped out of her clothes"Morechange into Sarah slipped into a black skirttake off, remove, pull off, doff, peel off she slipped out of her clothes

definitions.definition: insert a remark smoothly or adroitly into a conversation.
escape or get loose from (a means of restraint).
examples: the giant balloon slipped its moorings

definitions.definition: (of a remark) be uttered inadvertently.
(of a thought or fact) fail to be remembered by (one's mind or memory); elude (one's notice).
examples: a beautiful woman's address was never likely to slip his mind

definitions.definition: release (an animal, typically a hunting dog) from restraint.
move (a stitch) to the other needle without knitting it.
release (the clutch of a motor vehicle) slightly or for a moment.
(of an animal) produce (dead young) prematurely; abort.
an act of sliding unintentionally for a short distance.
examples: a single slip could send them plummeting down the mountainside
synonyms: tumble "a single slip could send them plummeting downward"

definitions.definition: a fall to a lower level or standard.
examples: a continued slip in house prices

definitions.definition: relative movement of an object or surface and a solid surface in contact with it.
a reduction in the movement of a pulley or other mechanism due to slipping of the belt, rope, etc.
a sideways movement of an aircraft in flight, typically downward toward the center of curvature of a turn.
the extent of relative horizontal displacement of corresponding points on either side of a fault plane.
a minor or careless mistake.
examples: the judge made a slip in his summing up

definitions.definition: a woman's loose-fitting, dress- or skirt-length undergarment, suspended by shoulder straps ( full slip ) or by an elasticized waistband ( half slip ).
a slope built leading into water, used for launching and landing boats and ships or for building and repairing them.
a space in which to dock a boat or ship, especially between two wharves or piers.
a leash that enables a dog to be released quickly.
short for slip stitch.
examples: one color at a time should be knitted in striped slip

definitions.definition: a small piece of paper, typically a form for writing on or one giving printed information.
a long, narrow strip of a thin material such as wood.
a cutting taken from a plant for grafting or planting; a scion.
examples: cutting, graft; Morescion, shoot, offshoot "they took slips from rare plants"Morescion, shoot, offshoot they took slips from rare plants

definitions.definition: a creamy mixture of clay, water, and typically a pigment, used especially for decorating earthenware.
